Black-footed Albatross: Has distinctly black feet, uncommon among seabirds
Laysan Albatross: Equipped with long, hooked bill and webbed feet for effective foraging
Sooty Albatross: Features a deep, sooty gray plumage, blending into the ocean's hues
Groove-billed Ani: Distinguished by its long, curved bill and black plumage
Crested Auklet: Legs and feet are uniformly black, matching its dark plumage
Least Auklet: White spots on black wings create a distinctive pattern for identification
Parakeet Auklet: Employs a short, black tail for maneuvering in tight coastal niches
Rhinoceros Auklet: Features a unique white face with black stripe behind the eye
Brewer Blackbird: Equipped with a long, curved beak for feeding
Red-winged Blackbird: Characterized by striking red and yellow wing markings on a black body
Rusty Blackbird: Black bill and legs complement its overall dark appearance
Yellow-headed Blackbird: Adapts well to wetland habitats, with a diet ranging from insects to seeds
Indigo Bunting: Black wings and tail accentuate its blue plumage.
Painted Bunting: Juvenile males and females are mostly green.
Cardinal: Males are vibrant red with a black mask around the face.
Spotted Catbird: Features a black head with distinctive white spots on the side
Gray Catbird: Slate grey bird with a black cap and tail, accented by a white belly
Eastern Towhee: Known for its long, curved bill and ground foraging behavior
Brandt Cormorant: Dark plumage overall with an iridescent sheen in sunlight.
Red-faced Cormorant: Dark plumage contrasts with striking red facial skin.
Pelagic Cormorant: Flight is low over the water with rapid wing beats.
Bronzed Cowbird: Known for its parasitic breeding habits
Shiny Cowbird: Males perform a distinctive bowing display during courtship.
Brown Creeper: Inhabits wooded areas across North America
American Crow: Omnivorous diet includes invertebrates, seeds, and waste.
Fish Crow: Equipped with long legs and webbed feet for aquatic foraging
Black-billed Cuckoo: Eats large quantities of caterpillars and insects
Mangrove Cuckoo: Nesting habits poorly understood due to secretive nature
Yellow-billed Cuckoo: Inhabits wooded areas where it feeds on insects
Gray-crowned-Rosy Finch: High elevation dweller, hardy against cold temperatures
Purple Finch: Conical bill for seed and fruit eating
Northern Flicker: Brown with black bars, distinctive red nape patch
Acadian Flycatcher: Inhabits dense forests and woodlands, near streams
Great-Crested Flycatcher: Medium-sized songbird with a mix of grey, brown, or black plumage
Least Flycatcher: Song is a sharp 'chebek', often repeated
Olive-sided Flycatcher: Long-distance migrant, winters in South America
Scissor-tailed Flycatcher: Pale gray body, strikingly long, forked tail, and salmon-pink flanks
Vermilion Flycatcher: Brilliant red in males, females paler with white belly
Yellow-bellied Flycatcher: Breeds in wet, northern forests, often near water
Northern Fulmar: Glides on stiff wings, petrel family, gray and white variations
Gadwall: Prefers freshwater lakes, marshes, and ponds
American Goldfinch: Breeds late in season, nests woven tightly and placed in shrubs
European Goldfinch: Distinctive liquid twittering song and call
Boat-tailed Grackle: Inhabits coastal marshes and urban areas
Eared Grebe: Excellent diver, feeds on aquatic invertebrates and fish
Horned Grebe: Known for its loud, trilling songs and aggressive territorial behavior
Pied-billed Grebe: Small waterbird with a unique bill pattern and webbed feet for diving
Western Grebe: Famed for its elaborate courtship dance, including synchronized water running
Blue Grosbeak: Equipped with a large, conical bill for seed and insect eating
Evening Grosbeak: Frequents sunflower feeders in winter, often in large, noisy flocks
Pine Grosbeak: Gentle, mellow call, often forming loose flocks outside of breeding season
Rose-breasted Grosbeak: Inhabits wooded areas and often found at bird feeders
Pigeon Guillemot: Dives for fish and invertebrates, uses wings to 'fly' underwater
California Gull: Known for their loud, laughing call
Glaucous-winged Gull: Characteristic heavy build with a robust head
Herring Gull: Classic seagull appearance with a white and grey palette
Ivory Gull: Nests on the ground in remote northern areas
Ring-billed Gull: Common across North America, often found in inland and coastal areas
Slaty-backed Gull: Hefty bill marked with red, mounted on a fierce face
Western Gull: Pinkish-white legs giving a sturdy stance
Anna Hummingbird: Small, vibrant bird with green and reddish plumage
Ruby-throated Hummingbird: Small bird distinguished by a brilliant red throat patch
Rufous Hummingbird: Prefers open areas, yards, and parks with plenty of flowers
Green Violetear: Brightly colored hummingbird with distinctive violet ear patch
Long-tailed Jaeger: Plumage varies from light gray to brown with white underparts
Pomarine Jaeger: Dark cap contrasting with lighter nape and underparts
Blue Jay: Intelligent, known for mimicking the calls of hawks
Florida Jay: Feeds on acorns, insects, and berries
Green Jay: Inhabits dense thickets and woodlands from Texas to Honduras
Dark-eyed Junco: Inhabits woodland edges, gardens, and parks
Tropical Kingbird: Feeds on flying insects which it catches in mid-air acrobatics
Gray Kingbird: Breeds in coastal areas, mangrove swamps, and islands
Belted Kingfisher: Distinctive rattling call heard along rivers and lakeshores
Green Kingfisher: Male has a broad chestnut breast band which the female lacks
Pied Kingfisher: Feeds predominantly on fish, diving headfirst into water to catch prey
Ringed Kingfisher: Distinct black band around the neck
White-breasted Kingfisher: Vibrant blue wings and orange feet
Red-legged Kittiwake: Usually silent at sea, but noisy at breeding colonies
Horned Lark: Notable for the small black 'horns' of feathers on its head
Pacific Loon: Markings include a white stripe above the eye
Mallard: Adaptable to various habitats, often found in urban and suburban ponds
Western Meadowlark: Yellow-breasted with a distinctive black V on chest
Hooded Merganser: Nests in tree cavities near water bodies
Mockingbird: White breast with black wings and white spots
Clark Nutcracker: Known for burying seeds as food storage
White-breasted Nuthatch: Slate blue-gray back with a stark white underpart
Baltimore Oriole: Weaves a hanging basket-like nest at the end of tree branches
Hooded Oriole: Long, curved beak for nectar feeding
Orchard Oriole: Song is a series of clear, whistled notes and chatters
Scott Oriole: Inclined to arid landscapes with yucca plants, which are used for nesting
Ovenbird: Can be difficult to spot, but often betrays its presence with its song
Brown Pelican: Plunges headfirst into water in spectacular fishing dives
White Pelican: One of the largest flying birds
Western-Wood Pewee: Small, brownish-grey with a long, black beak
Sayornis: Insectivorous, using acrobatic flights to catch prey
American Pipit: Flight call is a sharp 'pipit,' from which its name derives
Whip-poor Will: Camouflage plumage blends perfectly with leaf litter on the forest floor
Common Raven: All-black plumage with a large, curved beak
White-necked Raven: Highly opportunistic eater, including fruit, insects, and carrion
American Redstart: Males are black with bright patches, while females are gray with yellow patches
Loggerhead Shrike: Sharp, hooked bill for attacking and consuming prey
Great-Grey Shrike: Largest of the shrikes, with a broad black mask and pale gray body
Baird Sparrow: Rufous cap and streaked back help it blend into its surroundings
Black-throated Sparrow: Song is a clear, sweet series of whistles
Chipping Sparrow: White underparts distinguished by crisp black streaks
Clay-colored Sparrow: Prominent dark line extending through the eye
House Sparrow: Short and square tail lending to a chunkier silhouette
Field Sparrow: Brown back with a pink bill
Fox Sparrow: Hefty, dark bill designed for foraging in thick underbrush
Grasshopper Sparrow: Short, conical bill for seed consumption
Harris Sparrow: Dark eyes set against a lighter face, enhancing its distinct look
Le-Conte Sparrow: Fluttering flight with a soft, musical song
Lincoln Sparrow: Buff belly with a white ring around the eye
Nelson-Sharp-tailed Sparrow: Black bill sharply contrasting with lighter plumage
Seaside Sparrow: Dark face with a light grey breast
Song Sparrow: Dark streaks on a white breast
Tree Sparrow: Dark spot on clean grey breast
White-crowned Sparrow: Long, squared tail contributing to elegant proportions
White-throated Sparrow: Striking white throat patch, yellow lores
Barn Swallow: Distinctive reddish throat and forehead in adults
Cliff Swallow: Mud-built, gourd-shaped nests on vertical surfaces
Scarlet Tanager: Striking red plumage with black wings
Summer Tanager: Entirely red or yellow, depending on sex and age
Artic Tern: Famous for its long migratory journey, pole to pole
Caspian Tern: Nests on the ground on isolated beaches
Common Tern: Breeds in colonies on coasts, islands, and inland lakes
Elegant Tern: Breeding plumage shows a shaggy crest and a clean white body
Forsters Tern: Black cap in breeding season, white in winter
Least Tern: Sharp, rapid flight over shallow waters, catching small fish and crustaceans
Green-tailed Towhee: Prefers brushy habitats and chaparral for foraging and nesting
Brown Thrasher: Long rufous tail and curved bill for probing into leaf litter
Blue-headed Vireo: Compact songbird sporting a striking blue-grey head
Philadelphia Vireo: Song is a series of musical phrases
Red-eyed Vireo: Black bill, perfectly curved for precision
White-eyed Vireo: Forked tail, aiding in its acrobatic flights
Yellow-throated Vireo: Feeds on insects, often in treetops
Bay-breasted Warbler: Long, black tail, a rudder through the skies
Black-and-white Warbler: Song is a series of high-pitched notes
Black-throated-Blue Warbler: Black throat, a shadow amidst the light
Cerulean Warbler: White underparts with fine black streaks
Golden-winged Warbler: Song is a series of buzzes and trills
Hooded Warbler: Male has a distinctive black hood
Kentucky Warbler: Song is a loud, clear whistle
Magnolia Warbler: Black eye stripe for visual distinction
Mourning Warbler: Song is a mournful, slow trill
Nashville Warbler: Small, with a yellow belly and dark legs
Orange-crowned Warbler: Features a long, thin beak and a similarly long tail
Prairie Warbler: Its yellow throat brightens the white underparts
Prothonotary Warbler: Inhabit wet woodland areas, easily spotted by vivid coloring
Worm-eating Warbler: Yellow throat adding a splash of color
Yellow Warbler: Equipped with a black bill, ideal for insectivory
Northern Waterthrush: Sparrow-like bird with a distinct white throat and streaked underparts
Louisiana Waterthrush: Brown and white plumage with distinct streaks
Bohemian Waxwing: Noted for its unique red waxy wing tips
Cedar Waxwing: Yellow or orange beak contrasts with the black mask around its eyes
American-Three-toed Woodpecker: Features a black head with a central white stripe
Red-cockaded Woodpecker: Black and white plumage with red streaks
Downy Woodpecker: Small size with black and white plumage
Bewick Wren: Small, brown bird with a distinguished white belly
House Wren: Black tail with white bars for identification
Winter Wren: Two white bars on wings for identification
